newsitem.title: USA: Catastrophe insurance rates down 17 pct in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Catastrophe insurance rates down 17 pct in 1997.

text.p: The rate on line for large catastrophe excess of loss insurance programs fell 17 percent in the January renewal season, approaching pre-Hurricane Andrew levels, according to an industry report released today.

The report by global reinsurance intermediary Guy Carpenter & Co Inc was based on January insurance program renewals of major U.S. companies writing on a nationwide basis. Guy Carpenter is a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan Cos Inc.

Guy Carpenter's Monitor report found that even after factoring in the additional covers being bought by insurers, an average 10-15 percent savings was seen in overall property catastrophe reinsurance costs.
Decreases in rate on line are the result of changes in program structure, catastrophe terms or conditions as well as competition for premium dollars, the report said.
Reinsurance capacity, or supply, also remains abundant, the report said.

National insurers and regional companies with books of business that resemble large national insurers can easily attract $500 million of traditional capacity and up to $1 billion if traditional is combined with non-traditional, the report said.
For smaller, regional companies, as much as $300 million can be purchased, the report said.

Although capacity remains readily available, Guy Carpenter said in its report that it has not seen a significant increase in the program limit, or amount of reinsurance being purchased for large catastrophes.
Program limits remained steady at a projected $230 million for 1997, following sharp increases in the three years after the capacity crunch in 1993, the report said.
Instead, insurers are using the savings from decreases in the rate on line to buy more coverage for the smaller, more frequent catastrophe risk retained on their books.
As the size of the loss needed to trigger most large catastrophe reinsurance programs has increased over the last several years, some insurers are now retaining more of that lower-level risk.
And property insurers were hit in 1996 by an increasing number of smaller, but more frequent, catastrophe losses.
According to Property Claim Services, in 1996 there were 41 catastrophes that resulted in a record high of 3.8 million claims, producing $7.35 billion in insured losses, the report said.
But an event producing an insured industry loss of $3.5 billion is now needed before most catastrophe programs will attach, or go into effect, the report said.
The result has been a significant resurgence in demand for aggregate reinsurance cover, which provides protection for those frequent, smaller losses, the report said.
With the soft market, the rates for these products have proven to be attractive to insurers seeking to cede that risk.
In an aggregate cover, losses are accumulated throughout the term of the contract into a total dollar amount.
That amount is then subject to the insurer retaining a certain percentage or dollar amount of the losses.
All losses can then be added together and recovered thereafter.
Competition for property catastrophe premiums is expected to remain keen during the next major renewal period in April and May, Guy Carpenter said in the report.
((-- Patricia Vowinkel 212 859-1716))
